text: hello everyone my name is Kevin and I am
an associate solutions architect at AWS
today I'll be navigating through the
enhancements made the air messages for
user and group provisioning when using
IM identity center and how you can find
the messages within your AWS account
using cloud
trail i am identity center provides a
unified platform where you can manage
access to both your AWS accounts and
applications through one consolidated
service in order to simplify the process
of administrating monitoring and the
auditing of use permissions across the
entire AWS ecosystem i am a data center
can be used to connect AWS to your
existing active directory or ident
provider such as enter ID formerly known
as Azure Active Directory JumpCloud Octa
Google Workspaces and more to allow the
use of an existing pool of users and
groups within the AWS environment this
allows users of IM identity center to
access AWS accounts and applications
using existing organizational
credentials and reduce the overhead
associated with user management in
multiple identity
sources when connecting IM identity
settings to an existing active directory
or identity provider you can simplify
user provisioning and group management
by setting up automatic provisioning
through the skim protocol so that any
changes to users or groups that you make
within your external identity source
will automatically be reflected in AWS
but what happens when things don't go as
planned when users fail provision from
your external identity source to IM
identity center it can be due to a
number of common errors such as missing
required identity profile attributes
rate limiting incorrect attribute
mappings and more how do you effectively
troubleshoot and investigate these
issues when so many possible causes
exist this is where Cloud Trail can
assist as these provisioning errors are
logged within the Cloud Shell service to
provide you with more actionable
information that help you locate and
address the cause of the issue
cloudchain provides an event history of
your AWS account activity including
actions taken through the ads management
console AS SDKs command line tools and
other AS services in order to provide
you with a source of observable data
that can aid in security analysis
resource change tracking and
troubleshooting by default the event
history in Cloud Trail only shows the
last 90 days of your account's activity
but you can store the logs for a longer
period of time or indefinitely by
creating a trail a configuration within
a service that enables delivery of cloud
trail events to an S3 bucket but while
cloud trail is great for finding
information on activity has already
happened it can be difficult to know
exactly when an error occurs unless
you're notified of it for example by a
user raising a support ticket because
they are unable to sign in to AWS
to address this we can set up alarms
which can alert you when specific errors
occur so that you can more proactively
identify when these failures happen and
address them more immediately the
creation of alarms and alerts is done
through the Cloudatch service which
integrates natively with Cloudell events
cloudatch alarms allow you to monitor
metric such as the number of API errors
that occur and perform an action when
the alarm thresholds are met some
actions that can be performed include
sending a notification to a simple
notification service topic forming an
Amazon EC2 action invoking Lambda
functions and more let's navigate over
to the AIS console to see how you can
find air messages provisioning issues
that can occur while using ski
provisioning with IMA data center and
how you can set up a cloudatch alarm to
notify you when these events
happen in the AWS console you want to
search and click on the cloud shell
service click on event history
click on the drop-own menu under lookup
attributes and set it to event
name in the search bar next to lookup
attribute search for a relevant scheme
API i'll provide a full list of scheme
APIs towards the end of the video this
example I'll be using create user to
show an error message related to a user
provisioning issue
click on the settings icon next to the
search bar and enable error code as a
visible column to make it easier to
identify which event has the information
that we can use to aid our
troubleshooting select the relevant
cloud trail finding with an
arrow here the event record provides us
the JSON text of the API request we can
see that the develop information such as
event time which tells us when the error
occurred the event name which is the API
action that was performed and the error
code and error message which provides us
which detailed information about the
issue that occurred during this
operation in this example we can tell
that the error message states the
attribute name family name is required
this tells us that the user provisioning
from our identity source fails because
the user was missing a family name
attribute which is acquired for IM
identity center now if you want to set
an alert so we notify whenever an error
occurs we need to set up cloud trails to
send it events to cloudatch to do this
click on
trails click on a trail they want to
send events to in Cloudatch if you do
not have a trail listed here you need to
create
one verify that Cloudatch logs is
configured for the trail if not click on
edit next to Cloudatch
logs check the box for
enabled create or choose an existing log
group create or choose an existing IM
role click on save
changes after we finish setting up our
trail we can now go to Cloudatch service
to begin setting up our
alarm
before we begin creating a cloud watch
alarm we will need a set of metric
filter for our log group to filter
specific events and errors that we want
to monitor in this example I'll be
walking through the steps to filter and
create an alarm for create user failures
that occur to do this click on log
groups click on the log that you
configured for your trail click on
metric
filters click on create a metric filter
enter a filter pattern the one I'm using
will filter for any create user
errors click on
next enter a filter name metric name
space metric name and metric
value click on
next click on create metric filter
now we created a metric filter we can
begin creating alarm that will notify us
whenever create user error occurs to do
this click on all
alarms click on create
alarm click on select
metric search for the metric we
created click the check box next to
metric and click on select metric
for statistic change to a
sum select greater equal for the long
condition and input a threshold value of
one click on
next click on create new topic and
specify the email you wish sent
to click on create
topic click on next
name the
alarm click on next click on create
alarm with this we now have an alarm
that will send an email whenever a
create user error occurs you can expand
upon this by creating metric filters and
alarms from APIs and you must set up in
a dashboard in Cloudatch that will
provide a centralized view of alarms
error accounts and other information you
specify
the list of scheme API calls that
support name as cloud shell and they can
use their cloud to longs for the
following create group create user
delete group delete user get group get
schema get user list groups list
resource types list schemas list users
patch group patch user put user and
service provider
config with the enhancements made to
